REVIEW_BODY:
The views here are great, you can almost see Malaysia to the north, and the hills of Indonesia to the south on a clear day. It's a different view from the glitzy MBS and here you get a glimpse of what the nicer public HDB housing looks like.

I have been here many times and written a blog post on tips including what are the highlights for children and where are the nearest toilets. Just Google MummyEd Pinnacle.

We have been the roof of Marine Bay Sands a few years ago. The view for Sands and here is two different views. Originally, I am planning to here for the sunset, but cloudy for the day we visit. Never mind, the changing on the colour for the sky still attract the eyes ball very much.
Nothing much here except to view the proud built of The Housing & Development Board which is currently the most expensive public housing.

The pinnacle is one of the exemplary public housing developments: 5 towers linked by outdoor sky gardens at levels 26 and 50. Level 50 is open to visitors for a fee of $6 from lobby G. You need an MRT card, or pay $10 deposit for one. Well worth the visit! There was no-one there and my young teenagers enjoyed the views and the activity areas along the way. There is some nice landscaping and little play areas for smaller kids at the base of the towers, and of course the charming streets around Duxton hill.

REVIEW_TITLE: Different perspective of the Singapore skyline
REVIEW_BODY: Interesting to visit if you are close to Chinatown and you will get a different perspective of the Singapore skyline. The building and lifts are starting to look a bit dated but well maintained and very clean as with most of Singapore. As the other reviewers have stated, entrance is from Tower G only and you need to have a working EZ-Link card with you to top up at the entrance.
For just 6 Singapore dollars you can see great views as building is 51 floors .recommend it go during sunset

REVIEW_TITLE: A rooftop view of Singapore from a different perspective
REVIEW_BODY: Going to the top of the Pinnacle@Duxton is something that I recommend to anyone. It only costs S$ 6, and you can see many places in Singapore that you cannot see that close from Marina Bay Sands. For example, Chinatown, the Tanjong Pagar Port, Sentosa, among others. The view is better going North, South and West. The views towards the East are blocked by other tall buildings, so it is not possible to see most of Marina Bay Sands (only the tip of the top is visible), as well as other attractions in the city centre. You can spot Indonesia easily and if you are lucky and go during a clear day, you can even spot Malaysia and the silhouette of buildings in Johor Bahru.

Great views of the city. Visited around midday and the place was deserted. My three kids enjoyed picking out the places they knew. Got lost trying to locate the ticket office ( block 1G) before going in. The office is a tiny broom closet. Didn't have my EZ card with me but the staff member allowed us up after paying $6 each. Well worth the visit, a little run down but still has fantastic views. If you have a phone , take down the number of the management office/ ticket office as you may have to ring them to get back off the viewing deck to the elevators down.

It cost $6 and you need a MRT to be allowed access to the top floor and see Singapore from this unique building. There are 7 towers all connected and the public is allowed access to the top floor only. Well worth a look at Chinatown and the city skyscrapers from a different angle

REVIEW_TITLE: The most extraordinary rooftop in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY:
If you have the adequate Singapore transport card, if you find the small office on the ground floor of the building you can take the elevator to the 50th floor and admire the most breathtaking 360Â° view of Singapore.
The terrace is at the top of a city apartment high rise building
The vast terrace goes all round 2 towers together with trees, lawns, and even children's games.
The view has absolutely no equivalent.A must.

For a small entrance fee visitors can take the lift to the 50th floor and enjoy great views over Singapore including the harbour, Chinatown and CBD. On the top, it's almost like a little park. The Skybridge connects the various towers. There's also benches, trees, artwork and some things for kids to play with. At
this hight, there was a nice breeze during our visit. It also was not crowded while visiting on a Saturday. Visitor parking is available in the basement carpark.
We were heading to China town and decided to go to Skywalk on a whim: Easy to get there ( go to 1G), and great views of the city on all sides. $5 only. Bargain
Singapore's first and award-winning skyscraper public housing project. Visitors can, for S$5, access the skybridge on the 50th floor between 9am and 9.30pm daily, and admire the views all round.

This place definitely stands out if we're talking about public housing. There are something like 7 blocks of apartments joint together by a skybridge on the 26th floor and the main attraction on the 50th floor.
The views are amazing and you'll easily spend something like an hour just walking around and taking some really good photos. Weekdays are much better and I would highly recommend coming on a weekday since weekends tend to be somewhat crowded.
I came by on a weekend, some time around 6'ish to catch the sunset and just couldn't catch any peace and quiet. It's simply bustling with kids, other photographers, a handful of other tourists and even spotted a property agent or two bringing their prospective clients for a tour of the place.
On another occasion, I came by around 8pm on a weekday and you'll still catch amazing views of the entire city and it was so much better! The twinkling lights of the city, there was a strong wind blowing so it was cool and there were so much fewer people around so it gives you time to be alone, enjoying the peacefulness and tranquility.

Apart from the stunning structure at street level, this rooftop garden is an understated gem in the Downtown City district. Having been turned off by pricey rooftop bars (esp Marina Sands to name but a few) this site offers spectacular views 50 storeys up at a very modest sum, which serves upkeep of building. Wide open space to enjoy amazing views unhurried.
Although does not reach the ideal Esplanade waterfront you get an breathtaking view of the Container Shipyard, the outer City & Skyline looking East (masking the Marina Bay). All the same if you want a stunning view without burning your pocket then this is an ideal venue.
We weren't disappointed.
The cost is Sing$5pp & the tickets are restricted daily (to about 200 visitors i understand) so dont leave it too late.
Thankyou to the Buikding Management & residents for the public viewing platform :-)

One of the best views of Singapore for only $6.
Check out the website for all the details about getting there and times open etc...
A full 360 view where you can see downtown, sentosa island, China town, even all the way to Indonesia...
The website says it limits the number of non residents to 200 per day. Not sure how hard this is enforced.
You do need a metro EZ- Card to access the gates.
Take the metro to Outram Park, then exit G - Police Cantonment Complex.
Cross - Neil Rd and walk to the management office in tower 1g.
Not to miss in Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Come here for the panoramic views of the city
REVIEW_BODY: Intriguing architecture. The Sky Garden also offered one of the best panoramic views of the city, even to Sentosa! One of my favourite attractions in Singapore. Just a few blocks away from Chinatown, should be in your itinerary when visiting Chinatown.
Nice for a 2 hour + outing with many vantage points which allows you to see nice views of Singapore. But the entrance to get into it is somewhat of a hassle!
The rooftop walk at the Pinnacle@Duxton provides the most breathtaking views of Singapore. Go in the evening to watch the sun set

REVIEW_TITLE: A hidden gem - only $6 for the best views in Singapore!!
REVIEW_BODY: It's not hard to find the complex, but finding where to buy the tickets is a challenge. Go to Blk G and then walk as far down as you can and then there are signs for the management office. You need a NETS card (but almost everyone will have one for travel) and that's loaded for access. $6 cash and you go up to the 50th floor. I expected a small viewing gallery, in fact there's around 300m of walkway with stupendous views and various seating areas. I'm going to recommend it as a must do for all our visitors

Good city and Harbour view. Can come up to sky garden (50/f) to watch fireworks. Highest public housing in Singapore. U have to come and experience the night view (around late afternoon onwards). If you are a photograph taker, this place suits you.

We walked from Orchard to the Pinnacle and the only challenge was finding the entrance kiosk for pay for the lift, it was disappointing therefore when the two clerks sitting in the office looked up, saw us (the only people there), reached over and picked up sign reading "Back in 15 minutes" , pulled down the blind and left us standing. In the event we went off and got cool drinks from the minimart in the building and returned 20 minutes later to find the sign still up. I tapped on the window and reluctantly the sign was removed and we were able to buy tickets for the lift. A rather bad show I thought. However the view from the top is well worth the paltry entrance charge. A magnificent vista of the docks, the old railway station, over to the southern ridges and Mount Faber. We had the place almost to ourselves. It is interesting to see a different perspective of the City instead of just the business quarter and Gardens on the Bay and the charge is nominal unlike the highly priced Maria Bay Sands.
Nice place, not too crowded...Plenty of time to soal in the City views and spend a good amount of time on the top of the buildings.
What a cheap way of spending half a day! Awesome concept 50 floors up with outstanding vistas of Singapore. A must do for the photographer

We recommend coming here if only to appreciate the share scale of developement and how close/how many people can live together. It is really quite monumental and you only really feel it when there. Plenty of old shop house venues/restaurants nearby so this can be a trip add on. Be mindful that the Otram Park station is undergoing renovation so really check the exit to use otherwise you may end up walking in circles like us...

We got off the mrt at Outram park, just look up when you exit and you'll see the building. Walked about 10 mins to building G, ticket office is at level one. We had ezilink cards which were validated to allow entry at the 50th floor. It cost $6 each. We didn't have the correct money however the gentleman at the office was very polite. Probably easier if you do bring the correct dollars.
As suggested we were there around sunset and stayed until it got dark. Definitely recommended.
At the 50th floor there is a track with trees and gardens. Pretty sitting areas and lots of photo opportunities. An interesting and unique architectural experience. There is a drink vending machine at base of G. There are no toilets up there so best go at the train station.

REVIEW_TITLE: Spacious relaxing rooftop with magnificent city view
REVIEW_BODY: The rooftop was spacious with a series of different themes for relaxing. Itâs a long walk across the whole rooftop from block A to G, where you can enjoy various different Singapore views from the city to Keppel yard. Overall was a relaxing place and affordable at $6 per entrance for a Singapore city view. Itâs great regardless for a day or night view.

Pinnacles is a really unique building. It comprises of seven entirely residential 50 storey towers (making it the tallest residential building in the world), each connected by 500 meter sky-gardens on the 26th and 50th floors.

Please note, although you can enter any tower and take a lift up to the 50th floor, you will be greeted by a locked turnstile! So you must go to the small office at the foot of block G1. It costs $6 for non-residents to go up to see the view but you need to have an EZ travel card. Since we didn't have a travel card, the helpful man allowed us go up if we left a deposit with him in his office.

The views from the top were superb, although it's worth noting you can't see Marina Bay Sands. One side overlooked the colourful docks and the other side looked out across the terracotta roofs of Chinatown to the polished skyscrapers of the business district. My favourite was the Oasia hotel, almost entirely covered in vegetation.

We walked along the walkways that joined the seven towers and there were lots of plants, fixed furniture and even a park where I saw the biggest grasshopper I've ever seen.

First time went there after seen recommendation online. Can reach there by walking from outram park mrt station. Once reach there, need to go to Block 1G (only available to access from this block), then go to storey 1 to register yourself at the office. Pay $6 per person and register your EZ-link card because need to use the card to tap and access to the sky garden at 50th floor throught Lift A/Lift B. The sky garden has very nice view and can spend time walking around to enjoy the relaxing environment . Be prepared for the strong wind there. Overall the experience is good and relax.

REVIEW_TITLE: A beautiful lookout point for people
REVIEW_BODY: Costing $6 to go up the Duxton, visitors can look out towards Singapore's central business district area from a 50-storey lookout point. The Duxton is 51 storeys high and is a beautiful building in itself. It is recommended to come at 6-7pm to be able to enjoy the beautiful sunset while you are up at the lookout point.
This observation point allows to see the port and the city at quite low and affordable price ( 6S). Good that close to Chinatown.
award-winning. aerial views parallel to none. this is the blueprint for future public housing projects in the future...this building is history in the making & U gotta VISIT IT!!!

It was a bit of a struggle to work out how to get up to the 50th floor but we finally did it. I had read that we could use our MRT cards to we went up to the 50th floor of G block but then our cards wouldn't work to get us through the turnstile. So we went back down to the ground floor and then noticed a small office. The window and door on the office was shut but there was an open sign on the window so we knocked and the manager appeared behind the window. We then paid $6 each (had to be cash) to have our MRT cards registered so that we could use them to swipe us through the turnstile. The view was amazing and it's incredible to be able to walk all the way around the 7 towers. But just be careful when you are going in or out of the turnstile to be ready to push it as soon as you swipe your card otherwise you might lose your chance to go through and then you'll have to share the turnstile with your partner like I did. Luckily neither of us are overly large! As mentioned previously, it's a good idea to have a phone with you in case you have to ring the manager to rescue you.

REVIEW_TITLE: A panoramic view of Singapore city
REVIEW_BODY:
The Pinnacle@Duxton is an award-winning 50-storey residential complex near the Chinatown area Singapore. The complex has seven towers which are connected by the world's two longest sky gardens of 500 metres (1,600 ft) each, on both the 26th and 50th floors. The view of Singapore city & the harbour from the 50th floor is panoramic. There is an entry fee of S$6 per person.
It was great fun taking a long walk and identifying the several landmark buildings & tourist spots of Singapore from the top.

REVIEW_TITLE: The View is different than usual - so is the Service
REVIEW_BODY: One gets a different 180 degree view from the 50th floor of the Pinnacle@Duxton than the usual one from the Skypark at MBS. But one also gets a different service than usual. The tickets can be bought from a most grumpy attendant at the unassuming little management office at Block G. One needs a Singapore Ezy-Link card for registration, otherwise there is no access. The fee is SGD 6 p/P and has to be paid in cash. Everything looks run-down and not well maintained which is also rather unusual for Singapore. To go to the roof-top of the Pinnacle@Duxton is only worth it, if you really favour a different view over the skyline of Singapore.

REVIEW_TITLE: Don't go if you do not have a working phone
REVIEW_BODY: We were maybe unfortunate on the day we went as the management office was a seat at the end of a corridor, which we found with some difficulty and following advice from some locals. While we had our EZ card it appeared this was insufficient as we needed to be able to phone so the gate could be opened to allow us to come down. The advice was that without a phone it was difficult, which in fact meant no access. There was no measure of assistance where we could agree a time in advance for the gate to be opened. A wasted journey and overall disappointing. Not the usual helpful Singapore.
There are better commercial places for good Singapore views. But this is probably the first one build on a public housing project which is opened for both residence and public.
It was such a nice surprise to visit the skypark on top of the Pinnacle! You get wonderful views of the city.

REVIEW_TITLE: it's public flat that looks like private
REVIEW_BODY: design is unique and it is considered the pretties among all government public flat where the prices are going like private estates in prime area

Entry to skybridge only via G block building.
There is a small office there with a guy who takes cash S$6 and gives you receipt.
Now take lift go to 50th floor and there is a phone number written of the person whom u just met,call him and he will open gate for you to enter or you may use your ez link card to enter.
Machine will not charge if you have paid in cash.
Remember your entry gate and exit from that gate only.
Also they allow maximum 200 people to enter skybridge on a single day.
Hardly anyone there. Finding office to pay a bit of challenge and getting EZ pass to open gates to enter or leave required phoning office. But those paled into insignificance when you see the views

REVIEW_TITLE: Very cheap and nice way to look at singapore from 55th floor
REVIEW_BODY:
Pinnance at duxton is a HDB housing flat.on top of it there is a Huge sky park.

How to go - get down at Outram park MRT station and proceed to cantonment exit and go to the block G of the building. speak to the security there and tell tehme that you want to got to sky park.
Genenrally your EZ link card should work. if not, they will take 5 dollard and give you a recepit. They also ask you to call once you reach 55 floor to open the security gate for you.

Then it is up to you. how many views you wish to see, it has resting shelters shady places and open bences to enjoy.and offers numerous views of singapore in all directions,.

This is a Best alternative to Marina bay Sands which charges you around 30 - 40$ but limited space allowed.

This is a must for tourist in my view.

A hidden-in-plain-sight gem. A wonderfully architected public housing project with spectacular views of the city. You need to pay a nominal sum to go up, please pay and have an unforgettable experience!

REVIEW_TITLE: A small park in the sky
REVIEW_BODY: It is a terrace high in the sky. With benches for picnics and 360 degree view over Singapore. Good: cheap access, very few people, great view. Not so good: complicated access and exit, small elevators. Definitely worth the visit!

The 50th storey skybridge is well worth a visit. For an entry of $5 you can see great views of Singapore. When we were there were a few others and not busy at all. I get the feeling that not many people know of this place. Well they don't know what they are missing. If you pick a good sunny day the views are spectacular as you walk around the skybridge which links around six blocks. Access the website for advice how to get there and entry instructions.

REVIEW_TITLE: Would have been 5* had the ticketing been easier!
REVIEW_BODY:
Took the MRT to Tanjong Pagar then turned left exiting the station and walked 200m to The Pinnacle. Had a go to Tower F to buy a SGD$5pp (great value!) ticket to take the lift to floor 50. We were expected to then phone up the building concierge when we wanted to come down (to get through an exit turnstile), but as we had no local phone connection, instead we had to wave at CCTV cameras until after 10 minutes we were noticed and the turnstile released - all part of the experience!!
Gripe over. The seven towers are all linked so you can walk the whole way around with great views of the port and the non-bay side of the city. You cannot see Marina Bay, but you will see plenty and for the price it is definitely worth a visit, if you have time and have seen the central city area and the Botanic Gardens (top of Orchard Road and a gem!).
Tallest Housing estate in the city. City View especially during the night and some national events. Fireworks can be seen when you are at the rooftop (50 storey)

REVIEW_TITLE: Fascinating glimpse of Singapore apartment life
REVIEW_BODY: The Pinnacle@Duxton is a group of seven inter-connected 50 storey tower blocks just outside Chinatown. On two levels they are all linked by causeways, the upper one of which can be accessed by the public. Wonderful views of urban Singapore and also into the interior of the island and out to sea. If you are lucky enough to meet up with a talkative resident, as I was, you can learn a lot about not only these remarkable flats but also about Singapore life in general. At ground level these are nurseries, play areas and other communal facilities and also a really good food court. The latter has some really delicious and spicy buffalo wings! You do need a Tourist Card/EZ Link card so it can be programmed to let you through the turnstile on the 50th floor, and also a S$6 fee. Very few people seem to go there but I thought it was a terrific couple of hours.

Pinnacle@Duxton are seven connected towers located at Singapore's city center. The buildings are the world's tallest public residential buildings at a height of 159.7 m / 524 ft. The construction for Pinnacle@Duxton started on April 2005 and was completed in 2009 and it has 2 sky gardens located on the 26th and 50th floors. The 26th floor skybridge links all 7 towers.
The 50th floor skybridge is open to the public and you can enjoy scenic views of the city by paying $S5. Go to tower 1G which faces Cantonment Road to reach the lift to get to the skybridges. Call to check for opening time, it closes for Chinese New Year.

For a small entry fee of 6 dollars (cash only, but you will need an MRT EZ-link card or Singapore tourist pass card which is coded to provide your building access), you can ride the elevator to the 50th floor of this impressive complex of 7 conjoined public housing towers. At the 50th floor is a landscaped 'skypark' which joins the buildings and provides amazing views across Singapore.

It was not very busy when I was there so it's also quite a nice place to relax and take a break.

Highly recommended.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great views for a small fee
REVIEW_BODY: For 6 SG$ cash, you can enjoy a walk along the 50th floor skywalk as long as you want. Great views of Chinatown, downtown and parts of the harbour. You need to bring an ez-link (MRT) card as the access system manages gates by a card reader. Highly recommended!

REVIEW_TITLE: A pleasant surprise for a modest price!
REVIEW_BODY:
I would recommend this for the views alone, looking over the harbor, Sentosa Island and Mount Faber; however, it is also interesting from an architectural standpoint. I visited at 9am and had the whole place to myself.

For access you need to go to the MA Office at the bottom of Tower F, but be advised it is not signposted for tourists.

I used to live in Singapore and didnât know this was available. Worth a visit. You need and EZ link card and you need to pay 6 SGD. Around sunset is a nice time and then you can stay longer to enjoy the view in the evening. You need to pay / enter from Block G.

REVIEW_TITLE: Peaceful way to see the city.
REVIEW_BODY: This can be a bit of a pain to find, so make sure to look for block G and pay (ONLY 6SGD per person) at the small office. When you get up there, you'll be treated to outstanding views of the CBD, the port and various green areas. Given the price and how peaceful it is up there, this makes for a lovely, affordable way to see more of Singapore. Furthermore, there are a few extra bits up there to make it even more interesting notably climbing frame and podium from which you can take excellent pictures. I also really liked all the greenery so high up.

Still a relatively undiscovered attraction of Singapore. Cost $6.00 plus you must have an EZ card. the card is needed to operate the turnstile at the top to enter and exit the viewing platform. Make sure you have the correct amount as the guy in the office is not that helpful. There is a shop very close by to purchase drinks etc to take up with you. there are great views to be seen and lots of places to sit down and admire the view

REVIEW_TITLE: Amazing view in a quiet environment
REVIEW_BODY: One of the nicest rooftops in Singapore. You can enter by tower G with the mrt card at a very cheap price (6$) and the view is amazing (no mbs but you can clearly see chinatown and a lot of skyscrapers plus Sentosa and the ocean). The place is huge and very quiet because is not really crowded. I think the best time to visit it is at sunset!
See some great views of the Singapore Port and business districts and Chinatown from the top of these 50 storey blocks viewing platforms. Access from Cantonment Rd and a small $5 charge

REVIEW_TITLE: A very nice spot for weekday after-work relaxing date
REVIEW_BODY: The high view looks incredible and it's windy up there. It's nice walk on the sky bridge spanning a few blocks of building. There are seating areas provided and if there is not much visitors, it's a very nice place for small talk with your loved one while overseeing the skyline of the city. For 6 dollar entrance fee, I would say it's a bit pricey but it could be said it's worth it also because of the cleanly maintained environment. Would love to visit again soon.

Went there already late, around 8pm. The small management office was rather hard to find, despite all the arrows and direction given. I register with my EZ card to pay S$5, took certain elevator as directed, then gain entry by tapping the card to open the stile door. WARNING : you need to stand very close to the stile door, tap the card, wait until the signal sound and immediately push the stile round. Nobody would help you on this. Thankfully you could repeat and repeat the action until succeed. Oh, and you need to return by the same door. And that door frequently not working properly, it seems. When I got back the tap sensor was not working. Fortunately a kind couple helping by calling the office, asking the door to be opened manually from the control centre. May the Providence help you if you were in my place - foreigner, cannot make phone call, didn't know what to do - and nobody there to help.
The view was nice enough. For me it was too close to the city, so the lights were not as wonderful as it should. One could still see all the chaos of the busy city. And it was so dark up there. Not dangerous though, almost all level ground (some kids even roller-skating around) but perhaps some lights in the some areas would be nice. Small lightings on the far fences, that's all there was. There was a viewing point in the middle area where one could sit and enjoy the view from higher point, but there were a couple got into fight there, so I passed :) I would say the best time to be there maybe sunset or late afternoon/early evening.

The skypark is amazing. 7 buildings, joined together with 360 degree views of the CBD, harbour and everything in between. There are little areas on the rooftop: a "beach", cottage, playground...although food and drink is strictly prohibited.

If you can time your arrival at the end of the day you'll get the joy of both sun, sunset and nighttime viewing. It's also a lot cooler up on the 50th floor.

Take the MRT to Outram Park, follow the signs to Cantonment road and then look up...it's hard to miss! Walk all the way to block G - there's a little blink-and-you-might-miss-it window where you can pay the building manager $6 cash to load your EZ or tourist card to give you access to the 50th floor sky garden.

Make no mistakes about it, this is a residential building and you're just allowed access to their rooftop. You'll ride the elevator with residents going about their daily business. For $6 though, with very few other tourists around (hooray!) it's a brilliant spot.

REVIEW_TITLE: Birdseye View of the City from Chinatown
REVIEW_BODY: You can go to the SkyBridge at 50th Floor to see the view of Singapore. Just go to "G Building" and pay S$ 6 for the ticket and take elevator to 50th Floor.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great Views... So Long as You're Not a Photographer!
REVIEW_BODY: The views from the top of The Pinnacle @Duxton are pretty incredible, especially from the side overlooking the Chinatown heritage buildings and the financial centre. I was surprised to find that (although I went on a weekday evening) there was hardly another soul up there! The only downside was how difficult it was to make a photograph without railings in the shot. If you're into photography you're better paying the $23 SGD and heading up to the Skypark at the top of Marina Bay Sands - I'd gone to Duxton pretty much entirely for photographic reasons so it was a shade disappointing. The view was still interesting, though, and was good value at $5 - make sure if you do visit that you have an EZ Link card (you can get them in the SMRT stations) as that's the only method of payment and one is needed to get you through the turnstiles when you exit the elevator at the top floor.

Great views of the Financial District, the Port, Chinatown and other parts of Singapore.

For some reason the instructions on the Pinnacle @ Duxton mention using your EZ Link card at a self service machine in Block G to get a ticket to the sky deck, which I couldn't find. I managed to get in and out anyway but they really need to update this, as I suspect many probably walk away in frustration.

More than worth the $5 entry fee. Went in the evening and had no problems with the quota system.The housing complex is a fascinating piece of architecture in itself, so worth a look even if you don't want to go up to the sky deck.

An undiscovered attraction of Singapore. for $5 you get a great view from a very long observation area covering the tops of five buildings, From watching activity in the container docks to looking over Chinatown to been on the same high level of the skyscrapers it impresses. will be retuning at night for an alternative view

If you wish to enjoy scenic views of the city from the 50th storey in budget, and don't want to pay more to the Singapore Flyer or 1-Altitude, The Pinnacle @ Duxton is a good choice.

The Pinnacle @ Duxton actually is a residents building, only allow 200 peoples of public can access the 50th storey skybridge per day, in National day or new year eve or any special day, you hard to access according to the quota, because this is the good place to enjoy fireworks too.

As a tourist, taking MRT train is a best way to getting here, just alighting at Outram Park Station by NEL, and take exit G, follow the sight, you will see the higher building at the Exit G, Exit G is a Police Complex.

You may take a 5 minutes walk to the Block 1G, and the entry is just behind the bus stop, go to the managing office, and the entry will cost you $5.

The 50th storey skybridge commands a fine distant view, personal I will suggest entry on 6pm (and bring some snack and drink), you will meet a day view and sunset view, also night view, ...and in budget!

On the estate's website there's an information that you can pay for the ticket with your EZ Link card, but when I was there (Feb. '16) there was no such possibility - I had to pay cash.
The entrance is a bit hard to find (it's at the F tower).
The view's very impressive! But once you've got enough of admiring it, you need to get back to the elevator and it can be troublesome... With my foreign SIM card I couldn't make phone calls in Singapore, so there was no way for me to inform the concierge that I want to go back. I had to wait for some other visitor to open the door for me.
Ok so yes it's new and in a good location, but this is still just an HDB estate for residential living. It's not really a tourist attraction as such. Not worth going out of your way to see.
This is residential complex .Not for tourists.You give it a miss unless you want visit sometime living here.Not worth coming here.

REVIEW_TITLE: Best view in town for only 6 bucks
REVIEW_BODY:
Make your way through the other side of Chinatown and enjoy the exquisite refurbished shophouses on the way to the Duxton Pinnacles. Such a juxtaposition of architecture!

Be sure to bring your EZ card to pay at the management office in building G. Then take the lift to the top and enjoy a pleasant hour or so admiring the view while walking across connecting bridges in a garden setting. Best way to spend an afternoon!

This sky walk lives up to expectations as it provides the visitor with good views of Singapore. It is safe to walk around on the fiftieth floor platform as it has a wide walkway and double safety barriers. The sky walk is accessed by a lift! Be aware that visitors are charged to go to the sky walk and access is controlled. Also the tower blocks have some leakage issues which could make the visitor wary and the walk is closed during poor weather.

360Âº views of Singapore from the 50th storey skybridge. For me, mandatory visit. It costs 6$. You can pay it with your EZ-Link card at MA Office at Blk 1G, Level 1. Open to the public from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily.

REVIEW_TITLE: One of the best views of Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: No fancy restaurant or bar but a great 360 degree view on Singapore. On a clear day you can see the surrounding islands, Indonesia and Malaysia.

Excellent view of the city from the 50th floor. The garden is well kept though there are only a few shrubs, some trees but no lawn. Not a must see but if you have surplus time .. It costs around 6 sgd

Every time I come to Singapore I visit here. Its a great view and at $6.00 a bargain. As usual there were only1 or 2 people on the viewing area. You need an MRT card or a MRT tourist pass as this is used to operate the turnstyle gates
Went with Friends and we were all surprised with the 360 view! From there you can see Sentosa, the port, old China Town, big skyscrapers... must go when visiting Singapore!

REVIEW_TITLE: visitors visiting level 50 will need to get a MRT EZlink card from the train station and produce it at block G office an
REVIEW_BODY: visitors visiting level 50 will need to get a MRT EZlink card from the train station and produce it at block G office and a payment of $6 cash for entrance fee at the office itself. the card will be registered so that we can use to access into the skybridge and out from block G only. Do take note they don't sell the cards at the office so u will need to get 1 first before going to the office. And yes no amount will be deducted from the cards cause u will need to pay the entrance fee by cash only at the office, Other then that a good chill out place to see the sunset and skyline of singapore.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great views for 6$ with MRT card
REVIEW_BODY:
Hint to tourists: BEST view you'll get of Singapore. You will be at 50 storeys high- so I am speaking for tourists who want to get great shots of downtown Singapore and the financial district. This is the top of a residential building, but you can pay 6$ at the basement 1G floor to take the elevator to the top and see the view. BUT you must get an EZ card from the MRT stations to be able to qualify for such a deal.

You'll be able to see all of singapore from the top- you can see old Chinatown, Financial district, many of the areas that you will be traveling to ahead, or if you're nearing the end of your trip, a nice summary of your vacation. You can see Sentosa, the freight boats, and the buildings around you. This is a collection of 5 buildings that are about 1 million a flat I think to live here. Different buildings will have small little gardens and cute architectural seats to promote communal interaction and little lawns of grass. My only problem is that to prevent jumping off, they put a fence that is 3 foot from the railing you're already held behind by, so it's hard to get some shots b/c you are 4-5 feet from the edge and behind 2 railings. Bring a selfie stick to help you out with this part.

Hint: also try visiting the URA or the architectures buildings- you get to see awesome models and the urban history of this city. Look it up and read my review of what to see here- it's free and highly educational for those who are into urban design and planning.

REVIEW_TITLE: great views for a decent price!
REVIEW_BODY: the place has a spectacular view across the city, and you can see malysia sometimes too! the 26 story is a playground / gym/running track. go to the 50th story if your main visit is just to see the place. please note that only Lifts A,B,and E only go to the 50storey directly. overall, this was a cheap place and a wonderful attraction. (dont worry about how crowded it is, usually its not crowded)

REVIEW_TITLE: Do visit for a breathtaking view!
REVIEW_BODY:
It is not overtly "public". You can see these characteristic buildings from almost anywhere in Chinatown which is practically next door.

1. It costs S$6. You have to go inside at the basement close to the overpass. A man will sit inside a pretty small room - almost anonymously. You pay him. Then you take the lift up afterwards.

2. The Pinnacle@Duxton is an award-winning 50-storey residential development in Singapore's city center, next to the business district. The project features the world's two longest sky gardens of 500 metres each, on both the 26th and 50th floors.

3. You have access to the 50th floor. The views from there cover practically all of Singapore because you can go anywhere on the roof of the buildings which are connected by bridges (easy to see from the street, but not noticeable when you are on the roof.

4. Try to arrange a visit at around 5:30PM and stay until after sunset. The sun usually sets at between 7:00PM and 7:20PM depending on the time of the year.

It really is worth it - especially with children. They will awe at everything!

REVIEW_TITLE: Great views without hordes of tourists
REVIEW_BODY:
We visited during a weekday afternoon and it was easy to find. The ticket machine was out of action but there was a gentleman in the office who took the cash S$6 each and gave door access on our Singapore Tourist Pass cards. We were directors to the life and told to exit the same way.

Once in the roof here are great views in all directions. We walked all around on the roofs of the 5 buildings connected by walkways. We hardly saw anyone else whilst we were there. There are quirky seating areas where you can relax and take in the views.

Well worth a visit.

REVIEW_TITLE: Excetional views over Singapore at an unlikely place
REVIEW_BODY: This is a very special HDB Highrise in Chinatown. For six dollars you get to take the Luft to the 50.th floor and check out Singapore from there. There is some seating, even under trees up there. Warning - no toilets!

Most people take Singapore Flyer or Marina Bay Sands to have a view over Singapore. There is however another less known location to enjoy Singapore city view. A HDB apartment complex, linked together, has a nice rooftop walk. Entrance via block 6. Only 5 S$ per person.

REVIEW_TITLE: Check out local living and great views
REVIEW_BODY: Go to building G to find little office to pay the $5 to get access to the 50th floor. Nice view from up top. Take a casual walk around the top and take some pictures of the city and coastline.

REVIEW_TITLE: One of Singapore's best hidden gems
REVIEW_BODY:
This place is a must-see. It gives you the most awesome 360 degree view of the ever changing city and most of the time you have the place for your self.
There is a bus stop right in front of the entrance.
Go there, you won't regret it.
Nice place to visit day or night, it cost S$5 per person to visit and can stay as long as you want. A heaven for photo bug, especially on a clear day. Night scene is fantastic too.

One of the spot underated by many travellers but is such a gem to visit everytime you come to this complex. I visited it in daytime and even though the sun was harsh, I managed to have a complete stroll around the walk to see the city. In the evening, I went there again for a visit. After sunset, the whole city lights were gleaming beautifully and you can get the whole view of the city below, and the business district from afar.

Little does any know that this place also serve for diplomatic purpose. Officials from other countries are often invited to this place to have a view, and these VIP will sit in the higher room which is in the center of the walkway. Note this for your next Singapore trip.
